context: Laemmle, Jr. created a niche for the studio, beginning <b5_0>a series of horror films<b5_0/> which extended into the 1940s, affectionately dubbed Universal Horror. Among them are Frankenstein (<a0_0><a4_0>1931<a4_0/><a0_0/>), Dracula ( also in <b8_0>1931<b8_0/>), The Mummy (<b9_0>1932<b9_0/>) and The Invisible Man (<a1_0><b7_0>1933<b7_0/><a1_0/>). Other Laemmle productions of this period include <a2_0>Imitation of Life<a2_0/> (1934) and My Man Godfrey (<a3_0><b6_0>1936<b6_0/><a3_0/>).
